III.	Facility Identification
The OSI facility is located at 4545 South Racine Avenue in Chicago, Illinois. The facility processes ready to cook and fully cooked bacon and ground beef and processes and packages chili, beans and other kettle cooked specialties. The NAICS code for the processes at the facility is 311612.  Many areas of the plant are refrigerated to maintain temperature in the production and storage areas.

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one RMP regulated refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating meat products. 

An area map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. 

IV.	Hazard Assessment - Worst Case Scenario (WCS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worst case release scenario. 


V.	Hazard Assessment - Alternative Release Scenario (ARS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternate scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 


VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program. This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. An audit of the PSM program was conducted in March of 2012 and the next audit take place on, or before, March 27, 2015 in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years. The facility has a windsock present onsite (located on the top of the building over the engine room) for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release.

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 

IX.	Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are included in the facility's Emergency Response Plan.  

X.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of OSI's operations. OSI recently conducted an audit of their Process Safety Management Program and has dutifully implemented the recommendations from that audit. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Otto & Sons. In addition to the facility ERP, the plant is included in a community emergency response plan developed by the Cook County Local Emergency Planning Committee. 

XI.	Management Program
Otto & Sons has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This includes assigning a qualified person (or position) to have overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals need to be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Eric Napientek, Plant Manager, is responsible for overall implementation of the Risk Management Program.

¿	Compliance Audit - The facility has updated a site-specific compliance audit program to ensure compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years. The most recent compliance audit was completed on March 27, 2012 and the next compliance audit will be conducted no later than March 27, 2015.
¿	Hot Work Permits - OSI has implemented the hot work program and developed a best management practice for hot work and permits.

VII.	Five-Year Accident History
The OSI facility has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.

VIII.	Emergency Action Plan
OSI has developed an Emergency Action Plan to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and the authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of the release.

OSI has communicated and trained facility personnel on proper evacuation procedures and has had interaction with the Chicago Fire Department, Station 49. Response activities will be coordinated with the Cook County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and the Chicago Fire Department Station 49. This coordination effort includes providing the fire departments with site diagrams and hazardous material information.
